item.title: Tashfeen Malik, Suspect in California Attack, Remains Mystery to Relatives
item.description: Relatives in Pakistan struggled to reconcile the woman they described as having a promising future with the one accused of unleashing carnage in San Bernardino.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Knife Attack in London Subway Called ‘Terrorist Incident’
item.description: The police arrested a 29-year-old man in the assault, in which one person was seriously wounded, but did not say why they considered it a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Taliban Releases Audio Purported to Be of Their Leader
item.description: The Taliban said the recording was from Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, who in recent days was rumored to be killed or wounded in a shooting in Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, the supreme leader of the Taliban, in an undated photo.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Bomb Kills 3 During Raid
item.description: A man suspected of being an Islamist militant killed himself and two members of his family in northern Lebanon on Saturday when he set of explosives during an army raid on his home.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: A Nose for Police Work
item.description: The Vienna police say they have discovered a plantation with more than 700 marijuana plants at a warehouse close to a center for police dogs.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Bomb Explodes at Temple
item.description: A bomb was set off outside a Hindu temple in northern Bangladesh early Saturday, wounding at least six people, the police said.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Azerbaijan: 30 Missing After Rig Fire
item.description: One worker was killed, 30 were missing and 33 were rescued Saturday after a fire swept through a Caspian Sea oil platform owned by Azerbaijan’s state oil company Socar, the company said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: With Burundi’s President Sticking to Power, Violence Is on the Rise
item.description: Since April, when President Pierre Nkurunziza said he would run for a contentious third term, this country in central Africa has had an ominous cloud hanging over it.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: In May, a member of the governing party’s youth militia pleaded with soldiers to protect him from demonstrators in Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi.

item.title: Wary of Risks in Jubilee Year, Rome Is on Alert
item.description: Pope Francis has declared a yearlong Jubilee of Mercy that is expected to draw millions of visitors, and some Italians are concerned that Rome is not equipped to handle the attendant security concerns.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Workers installed metal detectors at St. Peter’s Square on Thursday, five days before the start of the Vatican’s yearlong Jubilee.

item.title: China Arrests at Least 3 Workers’ Rights Leaders Amid Rising Unrest
item.description: The arrests in southern China have prompted concern that a crackdown on civil society initiated by President Xi Jinping earlier this year may be broadening.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Denmark, a Green Energy Leader, Slows Pace of Its Spending
item.description: Denmark, which cut a renewable energy fund, may provide other nations with a lesson in how politics, economic concerns and ideological disputes can temper gains.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jens Dall Bentzen at a furnace in Sonderborg, Denmark, that is built on a design he developed with a government grant. It burns organic matter to generate heat.

item.title: Influx of Turkish Troops Angers Iraqi Officials
item.description: Turkey has sent more troops to northern Iraq to train Kurdish and Sunni Arab forces against the Islamic State, a move that officials in Baghdad called a violation of Iraqi sovereignty.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: A Chinese Folk Artist’s Descendants Are Split by the Government’s Use of Their Family Legacy
item.description: Figurines used to promote the “China Dream” of President Xi Jinping have become a point of contention as some relatives of the original sculptor, recalling mistreatment by the Communist Party, seek to keep politics out of their business.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clay figurines, made in a style recognized across China as historical folk art, are being used in a Communist propaganda campaign, “China Dream.” Relatives of the sculptor who founded the style and studio 200 years ago have objected to its appropriation.

item.title: Islamic State Says ‘Soldiers of Caliphate’ Attacked in San Bernardino
item.description: It was the first official claim of responsibility by the group after days of congratulatory messages posted on Twitter by its online supporters.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Chad Suspects Boko Haram in Island Attacks
item.description: The African nation is frequently attacked by the Islamist militants of the Boko Haram group, which has declared its allegiance to the Islamic State group.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: In Danger in Afghanistan, Unable to Flee
item.description: Under threat of an honor killing, a young couple cannot get a visa to leave Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: From right, Mohammad Ali and Zakia, and their daughter, Ruqia, held by Mohammad Ali’s mother.

item.title: In Scotland, Unlike America, Mass Shooting Led to Stricter Gun Laws
item.description: The outcry that greeted the killing of 16 children in Dunblane, Scotland, in 1996, spurred the British government to act in a way that has been a boon to public safety and a salve to collective grief.
item.dc:creator: AL BAKER
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the Dunblane primary school in Scotland, where a gunman walked into the gymnasium on March 13, 1996, and fatally shot 16 children and a teach before killing himself.

item.title: Nigeria’s Comics Pull Punch Lines From Deeper Social Ills
item.description: In a nation troubled by corruption, blackouts and the scourge of Boko Haram, stand-up comics are mining the misery for laughs and are more popular than ever.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Glenna Gordon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A comedy showcase in Lagos, Nigeria, in October. In recent years, stand-up comedy has become the country’s third-biggest form of entertainment after movies and music, industry experts say.

item.title: Facing Resistance in Texas, Syrian Refugees Find Temporary Sanctuary in New York
item.description: As Texas sues to block Syrian refugees from resettling inside its borders, Mayor Bill de Blasio said he welcomed a dozen Texas-bound arrivals to New York City "with open arms."
item.dc:creator: LIZ ROBBINS and C. J. HUGHES

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Attack Kills 8 Civilians at Camp for Displaced People
item.description: United Nations peacekeepers intervened in the attack, which also left five of the assailants dead and several other people wounded.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
